The Congress acknowledges Monsignor Ignatius McDermott's unwavering faith, compassion, and dedication to helping the needy, especially those struggling with alcohol and drug dependency. He is known as a "finisher" in a world filled with "starters," and his work has touched the lives of many, from the Governor of Illinois to the most vulnerable on the streets. Father Mac founded the Addiction Counseling Education Services in 1961 to provide counseling to alcoholics and substance abusers. He later expanded his work to the Chicago schools system, developing an alcohol education curriculum and a program to help addicted teenagers stay in school. This program was successful and became part of Illinois educational practices. Father Mac's work has had a lasting impact on the treatment community. In 1963, he founded the Central States Institute of Addiction, providing instruction on addiction and dependency. His dedication led to the creation of numerous programs benefiting many, addressing issues like drinking and driving, addiction in pregnant mothers, and decriminalizing public inebriates. Father Mac founded the Chicago Clergy Association for the Homeless Person and Haymarket Center at 75. Now at 94, Haymarket Center is the largest drug abuse treatment center in Chicago, serving 18,000 clients annually and setting a model for other programs nationwide. Father Mac continues his lifelong pursuit of helping individuals overcome addiction. Monsignor Ignatius McDermott will receive a Congressional Gold Medal for his contributions to the drug treatment community and his work as a priest and humanitarian. The gold medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary has the authority to create and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal, with proceeds covering costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items under the law. Proceeds from the sale can be used as authorized. SEC. 5. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to cover costs for medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will go back into the Fund.
